page.title: 15Landscape Chaldon Hills
page.content: The natural landscape is dominated by rolling downland ridges with dry, former river valleys between. One ridge runs East/West along the Southern boundary of the block and rises to a maximum height of 166 metres above sea level. Five ridges, with valleys between them run North/South. Downland ridges have been rounded by erosion and soil cover over the underlying chalk is very thin. Therefore what few trees and hedges do grow are very stunted and their shape is further distorted by the prevailing South Westerly winds. In contrast the valley floors are fertile and support more abundant growth such as the ancient Marley Wood.Other than the steeper valley sides, used as grazing and woodland, the remainder is used for cultivation.
